title: Llyn Ogwen Circular Walk Route

images.title: Eric Jones / Llyn Ogwen, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: One of the shallowest lakes in Snowdonia, the maximum depth being a little over 3m. It has an area of just under 30 hectares.

images.title: Trevor Rickard / Llyn Ogwen, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: View west from the point where Afon Denau enters the lake. On the horizon, left is Y Garn and right is Foel Goch. On the right, the slopes of Pen yr Ole Wen sweep down to the lake.

images.title: Nigel Brown / Llyn Ogwen, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The lake with Foel Goch the mountain in the distance.

images.title: Garth Newton / Llyn Ogwen, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Legend has it Sir Bedivere, the last surviving Arthurian knight, cast Excalibur into the water here.

images.title: Waterfall at the west end of Llyn Ogwen by Chris Worsley, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Waterfall at the west end of Llyn Ogwen

images.title: The river Ogwen cascades down into the valley by Chris Worsley, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The river Ogwen cascades down into the valley

images.title: Eric Jones / The Car Park at Ogwen
images.caption: The Car Park at Ogwen. This photograph was taken from near the entrance to Ogwen Cottage - the LEA hostel. The ridge in the background is Y Llymllwyd, a spur of Foel Goch.

images.title: Bridge carrying the A5 over the Nant Ffrancon by Dave Spicer, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Bridge carrying the A5 over the Nant Ffrancon at the western end of the lake.

description: This circular walk takes you around Llyn Ogwen in the Snowdonia. You'll also visit the beautiful Ogwen waterfall at the western end of the lake. There's great views over the lake to the surrounding hills and mountains. The views of Tryfan are particularly good as it is located just to the south of the lake. You can start the walk from the Tryfan car park on the southern side of the lake. You then follow the lakeside pavement to the waterfall before picking up footpaths above the lake on the northern side. It's easy to extend your walking in this beautiful area. You can head up to the hanging valley at Cwm Idwal and visit Llyn Idwal on the way.
